title: 106_hr238
content: In fiscal years 2001-2005, the Attorney General must increase the number of personnel dedicated to combating alien smuggling by at least 50 positions each year. Additionally, criminal sentences and fines for alien smuggling will be increased. The United States Sentencing Commission will amend sentencing guidelines for alien smuggling, doubling minimum prison terms and increasing fines. The United States Sentencing Commission will amend sentencing guidelines for alien smuggling by increasing fines and minimum prison terms, as well as enhancing penalties for causing bodily harm or injury. Exceptions include offenses committed non-profit or involving only the defendant's spouse or child. Exceptions include offenses involving only the defendant's spouse or child. The text chunk discusses the elimination of penalties for individuals providing emergency assistance to aliens in life-threatening situations under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Additionally, it mentions amendments to sentencing guidelines related to prosecutorial policies. The United States Sentencing Commission will amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to address plea bargaining and prosecutorial policies. Differences in policies among districts will not justify deviating from the guidelines range. Enhanced penalties for individuals committing offenses while armed will be implemented. The amendments to Section 924(c)(1) of title 18, United States Code, include adding violations of section 274(a)(1)(A) of the Immigration and Nationality Act as offenses. The effective date for these changes is 90 days after the enactment of the Act. The amendments to Section 924(c)(1) of title 18, United States Code, will take effect 90 days after the enactment of this Act and apply to offenses committed after that 90-day period. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Funds are authorized to be appropriated to the Immigration and Naturalization Service for conducting undercover investigations and prosecuting violations related to alien smuggling. Amounts remain available until expended. SEC. 7. ALIEN SMUGGLING DEFINED. "Alien smuggling" refers to prohibited acts under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Passed the House of Representatives on October 3, 2000. Clerk attested.
